title: Boeing will invest $20 million in Virgin Galactic to design a vessel that can travel at 5 times the speed of sound
text:
According to a Virgin Galactic press release, US aerospace giant Boeing will invest $20 million in Branson's company to help develop commercial flights.

Virgin Galactic plans to send its first tourists into space with SpaceShipTwo by the summer of 2020, according to the company's latest statements.

A report in The Washington Post explains that the two companies want to develop a vessel that can travel at five times the speed of sound.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

According to a Virgin Galactic press release, US aerospace giant Boeing will invest $20 million in Branson's company to help develop commercial flights.

Through its investment fund, Boeing HorizonX Ventures, Virgin Galactic said in a statement that "the companies will work together to broaden commercial space access and transform global travel technologies".

Virgin Galactic plans to send its first tourists into space by the summer of 2020, according to the company's latest statements.

"Boeing's strategic investment facilitates our effort to drive the commercialization of space and broaden consumer access to safe, efficient, and environmentally responsible new forms of transportation," said senior managing director of Boeing HorizonX Ventures, Brian Schettler.

Read more: Richard Branson wants Virgin Galactic to send people to space every 32 hours by 2023

"Our work with Virgin Galactic and others will help unlock the future of space travel and high-speed mobility," he concluded.

Boeing hasn't had much of a focus on suborbital flights but, as of 2020, Virgin Galactic will allegedly be offering trips in its vessel, SpaceShipTwo, that provide a few minutes of weightlessness to six passengers at a time, as well as views of the curvature of the Earth.

The vehicle will be capable of moving at five times the speed of sound

According to The Washington Post, the two companies aim to develop a vehicle that can travel at five times the speed of sound across the globe.

George Whitesides, CEO of Virgin Galactic, told the Washington Post that the objective was to use Boeing's aviation expertise in conjunction with Virgin Galactic's work on new propulsion systems and materials, to design a next-generation transportation system that would be economically viable.

Since the Concorde, whose flights were stopped in 2003, no company has been able to find an economically viable model offering supersonic commercial aircraft.

According to TechCrunch, Virgin Galactic announced last July that it intended to go public as part of an agreement with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), created by the venture capital firms Social Capital and Hedosophia.

After this IPO, Boeing should receive shares in this new package and further details on Boeing's investment in Virgin Galactic are expected to be revealed later, according to Virgin Galactic's press release.

To date, Virgin Galactic has been financed by Richard Branson's own fortune, estimated by the Bloomberg index to be somewhere in the region of $4.73 billion.

The billionaire has allegedly spent between $1 billion and $1.3 billion on his three space companies, Virgin Galactic, The Spaceship Company, and Virgin Orbit.
